translation2: All Bosch electric tools, pneumatic tools, and measuring tools undergo careful inspection, testing, and are subject to the strict controls of the Bosch Quality Assurance. Bosch therefore provides a warranty for Bosch electric tools, pneumatic tools, and measuring tools. The customer's warranty claims under the purchase contract with the seller, as well as legal rights, are not restricted by this warranty. For these tools, we provide warranty in accordance with the following conditions: We provide warranty in accordance with the following rules (numbers 2-7) by repairing the defective tool, which is proven to be due to a material or manufacturing defect within the warranty period. The warranty period is 24 months, for commercial or professional use or equivalent usage 12 months. The warranty period begins with the purchase by the first end-user. The date on the original purchase receipt is decisive. For all tools purchased after September 1, 2004, the warranty period is extended to 36 months, provided the customer registers the tool within 4 weeks of the purchase date. Accumulators and charging equipment, as well as accessories supplied, are excluded from this warranty extension. Registration can only be done online at www.bosch-pt.com/warranty. As proof, the registration certificate, which must be printed immediately, and the original purchase receipt, from which the purchase date can be read, are required. Registration is only possible if the customer agrees to the storage of their data there. Excluded from the warranty are parts that are subject to wear and tear due to normal use or other natural causes, as well as defects in the tool that are due to normal use, abnormal environmental conditions, foreign operating conditions, overloading, or insufficient maintenance or care. Defects caused by the use of non-Bosch accessories, replacement parts, or spare parts are also excluded. Modified or customized tools are also excluded. Slight deviations from the specified properties, which are insignificant for the value and usability of the tool, are also excluded. The repair of the defective tool, which is recognized as a warranty claim by us, is carried out in the manner that we choose, either by repairing the defective tool or by replacing it with a fault-free tool (if available) or a successor model. Replaced tools or parts become our property.
reference: All Bosch electronic, compressed air and measuring tools are carefully examined and tested and undergo the strictest review from Bosch quality assurance. Bosch provides thereby warranty for Bosch electronic, compressed air and measuring tools. This warranty does not limit buyer’s warranty claims for defects that come from the contract of purchase with the seller as well as their legal rights. We offer warranty for this tool under the following conditions: We offer a warranty according to the measures of the following provisions (No. 2-7) via free repair of the tool defect, which can demonstrably be traced back to a material or manufacturing error on the part of the manufacturer within the warranty period. The warranty period is 24 months, 12 months for commercial, professional or similar usage. The warranty period begins with the purchase by the first end customer. The authoritative date is on the original receipt of purchase. If the buyer registered the tools within the first 4 weeks after the date of purchase, then all commercial blue electronic tools and measuring tools (excluding high-frequency tools, industrial battery-powered screwdrivers and compressed air tools) purchased since September 1st, 2004 have an extended warranty period of 36 months. Battery packs and charging stations as well as accessories delivered with them are excluded from this extended warranty period. The registration can take place online at www.bosch-pt.com/warranty. The registration receipt serves as a confirmation, which needs to be printed out immediately, just like the original receipt of purchase, which determines the date of purchase. Registration is then only possible if the buyer consents to the saving of the data which they provide there. Not included in the warranty are: Parts subject to wear from use or other natural wear and tear, and defects in the tool due to use or other natural wear and tear, abnormal environmental conditions, extraneous operating conditions, overloading or can be traced back to a lack of maintenance or care. Tools which were damaged during use with accessory, complimentary or replacement parts which are not Bosch’s original parts. Tools, which have undergone changes or supplementations. Minor deviations from the intended product that do not significantly decrease the value or usability of the tool. The repair of faults which are recognized as covered by the warranty occur in this fashion: we repair the faulty tool free of charge though our method or by replacing it with a functioning tool (if necessary by a subsequent model). Replaced tools or parts then become our property.

translation2: Translation:  Is it really that safe to choose tires when riding a bike? I woke up early this morning with a lot of excitement because I wanted to train for my upcoming bike tour in the next week. I got on my new bike that I bought on eBay yesterday and started riding. The first 40 kilometers were great, but then something happened that I had been expecting (this time in Krefeld). There were glass shards on the road. Zack, loud hissing, and my rear tire didn't want to continue the rest of the way. Since I couldn't get a replacement tire and inner tube on the weekend, I had to turn back and take the first bike path home. It wasn't that bad, but it wasn't great either. Maybe it's better if I practice changing tires before my bike tour. Now I'm facing a question and hope you can help me. Since I have a long route over several days ahead of me, I don't want to encounter this problem again. It wasn't that bad this time, as the old tires from the previous owner (a very nice old man who picked up the bike at 14:00 and had ridden 120 kilometers on them) and the ones he considered suboptimal because he had been riding them for several years. If I think about it, I'll need to change tires after 80-90 kilometers. I'm really not in the mood for that. Now I'm talking to an older man at the train station who asked me why I didn't use Marathon Plus tires; they're supposed to be puncture-proof. It all sounds very tempting. But are they really that puncture-proof? I don't have much enthusiasm left to spend 40 euros on tires and be disappointed. Moreover, I'm wondering if it's a problem that I'm using 25x622 on my bike. There are Marathon Plus tires available, but most of them are wider. Is this a problem? Or would you recommend a different tire for a bike? The Schwalbe website seems to recommend the Durano DD. Thank you in advance for your help, and have a great day!
reference: Picking tires for a road bike - life without popped tires? This morning I woke up with a fiery drive because I still wanted to at least train a bit in the upcoming weeks in preparation for my upcoming bicycle tour. It was as easy as that and I drove my road bike which I had bought on eBay the day before. The first 40 km were really beautiful - but then that happened which is always waiting for you in the intercity (this time: thanks goes to Krefeld!). Glass shards on the road. Pop, a loud hiss and my back tire was no longer up for riding the rest of the trip. Because of it being a work day, I didn’t really have the chance to acquire a spare tire and tube, I had to turn back halfway through in a bad mood and take the next workable train back home. It was not the worst downer ever, maybe it is even better if I practice changing tires one more time before I leave to go on the tour. But now I am posed with a question and hope that you will be able to help me. Because I have a relatively long stretch of road and many days in front of me, I would very much like to not run into this problem on a regular basis. This time it really wasn’t that bad, because the tires were from the previous owner (a very nice old man, who had already rode 120 km by 2 PM on the day I came to pick up my bicycle) and because he had described them as suboptimal, because he had already been wearing them down for many years. But if I think about having to change tires every 80-90 km on the tour, then I am already in a really bad mood :D I just got into a discussion with an older man at the train platform, who asked me quite surprised, why I don’t have the Marathon Plus tires, these are supposed to be impossible to pop. Now that certainly does sound tempting. But are they really so indestructible? I have no desire to give out €40 per tire in order to just be disappointed. At the same time, I ask myself: I am using 25x622 race tires at the moment, I believe. This is (apparently?) just like the Marathon Plus tires, but the majority of tires are actually wider. Is that the real problem? Or would you recommend that I really get different tires in general for the road bike? The Schwalbe website seems to be of one opinion! Would common sense tend to recommend the Durano DD? Thank you in advance for your help and take care!

translation2: Statement of a Community Worker in Opposition to the Constitution Hallo r/LegaladviceGerman, I have the following problem. On our property, a walnut tree is to be felled. On the other hand, the constitution is clear. Thank you for your responses.

A felling application has been sent to the community. A colleague wrote to me that the felling of fruit trees, which then would include the walnut tree, is not part of the bylaws. Walnut trees are not specifically listed in the bylaws, however. Can I still trust the statement of my colleague or not? On the one hand, I really must rely on the opinion of an expert. On the other hand, the bylaws are pretty clear. Thank you for your answer

translation2: "The Party We Wanted to Celebrate": Frankfurt's Spectacular Comeback Against Leverkusen  Frankfurt is celebrating after a thrilling 5-2 victory over Leverkusen in the Bundesliga. After 22 minutes, the Hessen team, who had lost their last two games in a row, found themselves on the brink of another Bundesliga crisis. But then, the SGE turned things around, scoring four goals in just over an hour to leave their frustrations behind and win fiercely.  "It's insane what the boys did today," said trainer Oliver Glasner on DAZN, giving a "praiseworthy performance to everyone who was there." At first, it looked like another setback for the now ninth-placed Frankfurt, with Patrik Schick putting Leverkusen in a 2-0 lead. But what happened next left even the SGE trainer speechless.  "How the players came back and put on a fantastic performance," said Glasner. "I'm absolutely crazy happy with the performance we showed and, of course, with the result. Even Christopher Lenz, who had been out for four games due to a muscle injury, was back on the field and boosted the morale of his teammates.  "I believe our mental strength is unbelievable," said the 27-year-old. "I'm especially happy for the fans. That was the party we wanted to celebrate today."  Glasner now wants to focus on the upcoming tasks, but he is optimistic about the team's prospects. "It's amazing that we have all our players fit in December, that they are all physically in top shape," said the trainer. "It's top-notch work in our medical department, but the players also live professionally."  Now, the team needs to "take it step by step and remain humble" while continuing to perform at this level until the end of the year. The next challenge comes on Wednesday, with an away game against Borussia Mönchengladbach (18:30, Sky).
reference: “A Party we wanted to throw”: Frankfurt is celebrating after a high scoring comeback against Leverkusen What a spectacular reaction from Eintracht Frankfurt. After 22 minutes, the team from Hessen, which had recently lost twice in a row, seemed to be on its way to its next soccer failure. But then the SGE turned themselves around and were able to shoot the frustration of a poor start to the season out of their soul within an hour, leading to a furious 5-2 victory. “It was crazy what the boys were able to accomplish today,” Coach Oliver Glasner said with jubilee at DAZN and spoke of “praise all around, to each and every one of them who were there”. At the beginning, it seemed like another setback for the team from Frankfurt, who are now at place nine and still not living up to their expectations. Patrik Schick brought the team from Leverkusen to a 2-0 lead. What happened next deeply effected the SGE coach. “The way the players were able to take it back and display a fantastic performance,” according to Glasner. I am extremely happy with the performance, which we showed and also with the result. Defender Christopher Lenz, who was playing for the first time since the fourth game day and overcoming his muscle injury, really emphasized team moral. “I think that our mentality is unbelievably great”, the 27-year-old said and was happy after checking the scoreboard, especially how it effects the viewers. That was the party that we wanted to throw today. However, Glasner still wants to keep focused for the upcoming challenges, but sees himself well set when considering his personal situation. It is extraordinary that all of us players are so fit in December, that we are in tip top shape. It is pristine work by our medical department, but our players are also living extremely professionally. Now we want to “keep going step for step and stay determined” and “execute at this same level” the challenges up until the years end. Next on the docket is an away game at Borussia Mönchengladbach (6:30 PM, Sky) on Wednesday as part of English week.

translation2: Problems with Fiber and Devolo DLan/Magic  We have had a new fiber optic connection in our house for a few weeks now. Unfortunately, I am now experiencing problems building a stable WiFi network. Previously, I had a DSL 50 Mbit connection and used Devolo DLan, which received and transmitted 50 Mbit without any issues, except for a few failures. The new fiber optic connection sends 500 Mbit to the FritzBox 7590 and the DLan module connected to it also receives these speeds. However, on the other DLan module, which is used to transmit WiFi, the speeds are no longer the full 500 Mbit, but rather decrease as I move further away from the module (for example, using a power socket that is 1, 2, 3, etc. rooms away from the other module). This results in slower internet speeds on the first floor, even though the new fiber optic connection is supposed to be much faster (\~45 Mbit). I also ordered a new Devolo Magic Set, which supposedly uses new technology. Although it was slightly better than the DLan, there were still significant losses. Can someone explain why so much internet speed is lost when using fiber optics through the power lines? And is LAN really the only solution? It would be extremely expensive to lay LAN cables throughout the house. I am really frustrated, which is why I created this account. Therefore, I would greatly appreciate a response.
reference: Problems with fiber optic + Devolo Dlan/Magic We got a new fiber optic cable connected to the house a few weeks ago. Unfortunately, I am now having problems building a stable WiFi connection. Previously, I had a DSL 50 Mbit connection and used Devolo DLan, which received and sent out a smooth 50 Mbit with just a few exceptions. The new fiber optic connection sends 500 Mbit to the FritzBox 7590 and this also comes to the DLan module, which is connected to the FritzBox. Having said this, the full 500 is not received by the other DLan module, which is sending out the WiFi, but rather the more I move away from the module within the house, the less it receives (using an outlet, which is 1, 2, 3, etc. rooms away from the other module). That means that the internet with the new fiber optic connection is now slower on the second floor than it was before (\~45 Mbit). I ordered a new Devolo Magic set as well, which is supposed to be using a new technology. This was slightly better than the DLan, but it still lead to similar, significant losses. Can someone please explain to me how so much internet speed is “going lost” through the power line? And is LAN really the only solution? It would be extremely time consuming to also lay LAN cables all over the house. I am really at a loss here, which is why I have created an extra account here. That is why I would be so happy about getting an answer.

translation2: Since its introduction in 2001, the Valvetronix series from VOX has continuously evolved, leading to the combination of advanced modeling technology with the "Valve Reactor" circuit, which perfectly reproduces the behavior of a vacuum tube amplifier. With the VT20X/VT40X/VT100X amps, we present a brand new modeling engine that is absolutely state-of-the-art in terms of sound. Thanks to the VET technology (Virtual Element Technology), which is based on the analysis of components and amplifier circuits, the VTX amplifiers offer an authenticity that is simply impressive. These amps also contain the multi-stage Valvetronix vacuum tube preamplifier, which is partly based on real analog circuits because they better capture the tone variations and nuances of a vacuum tube amplifier than any simulation. In addition to this sophisticated circuit, the VTX amplifiers feature a closed enclosure and a bass reflex system, which allows the natural resonances to sparkle only so much. With the "Tone Room" software from VOX, you can correct and distort historical facts on the virtual level, so that the amp and effects sound exactly as you always imagined. The perfect combination of vacuum tube sound with modeling technology is mainly due to the 2001 introduced VOX Valve Reactor technology. Although it has been refined several times since then to meet new sound requirements, it was again responsible for a power boost of the VOX Valvetronix series in 2010 - with more dynamics and a variety of improved amplifier models. From the handheld VT20+ to the VT120+ with two speakers, the new VT+ Valvetronix series has been designed so that all guitarists looking for a maximum sound variety will find it here. All guitarists dream of the pressure and dynamics of a vacuum tube amplifier: they expect a fat sound, a nuanced reproduction of playing dynamics and string strikes, and a quick response. During an incoming analysis, VOX engineers discovered that above all the output stage determines the character of a vacuum tube amplifier and developed the VOX Valve Reactor technology based on this finding. The Valve Reactor circuit of each VT+-amplifier is equipped with a 12AX7 vacuum tube, which perfectly reproduces the behavior, the subtle nuances and the sound character of a vacuum tube amplifier.
reference: Since its introduction in 2001, the Valvetronix series from VOX has continuously been improved, which has lead to, among other things, the combination of groundbreaking modeling technology with the “Valve Reactor” circuit with which the behavior of a tube amplifies is perfectly reproduced. With the VT20X/VT40X/VT100X amps, we present a brand-new modeling engine, which is the absolute state-of-the-art in the field of sound. Thanks to VET technology (Virtual Element Technology), which utilizes an analysis of the components and amp circuits, the VTX amplifier puts forth an authenticity, which is absolutely impressive. These amps also include the multi-leveled Valvetronix tube amplifiers, of course. This deals with real analogue circuits, because these simply are better than any simulation at obtaining the sound variations and nuances of a tube amplifier. In addition to this sophisticated circuitry, the VTX amplifier offers a closed casing and bass reflex system, from which natural resonances just burst out. With VOX’s “Tone Room” software, you can even correct and bend historical facts on a virtual plane until the amp and the effects sound just like you have always imagined them. The perfect combination of tube sound with modeling technology is above all thanks to the VOX valve reactor technology introduced in 2001. Naturally, it has been refined ever since then in order to handle new sound requirements, which in 2010 lead to a renewed power boost to the VOX Valvetronix series with more dynamics as well as numerous, decisively improved amplifier models. From the handy VT20+ to the VT120+ with two speakers, the new VT+ Valvetronix series has additionally been designed in such a way that all guitarists looking for maximum sound variety will find what they need here. All guitarists dream of the pressure and the dynamics of a tube amp: They want a fat sound, a nuanced playback of playing dynamics and chord strokes, as well as a prompt response. During an in-depth analysis the VOX engineers discovered that the output stage above all else determines the tube character of an amplifier and they developed the VOX Valve reactor technology on the basis of this discovery. The Valve reactor circuit of any VT+ amplifier equipped with a 12AX7 tube produces the character, the subtle nuances and the sound shape of a tube amplifier perfectly.

translation2: Bundesbauministerin Klara Geywitz: No New Housing Through Expropriation The new Federal Minister for Housing, Klara Geywitz (SPD), has spoken out against expropriation of large housing corporations, as has been proposed in a referendum in Berlin. "With expropriation, no new housing units are created, only the ownership structure changes," said Geywitz in an interview with the "Tagesspiegel" (Sunday). My goal is to ensure that tenants have security, so that their rent remains affordable in the next few years. A diverse mix of, for example, private landlords, cooperatives, or housing companies is actually the best protection against monopolization. In Berlin, the coalition of SPD, Greens, and Left Party plans to set up an expert commission to determine how to proceed with the result of the referendum. If the situation does not improve, Geywitz has indicated that she is willing to hold talks with the FDP in the coalition government about further strengthening rent laws. The coalition agreement includes a rent brake until 2029, a limit on rent increases in tight housing markets, and the expansion of the rent index. I will speak with the Justice Minister to implement this as quickly as possible. If the housing market does not improve, "we will talk with our coalition partners about further steps," emphasized the SPD politician.
reference: Federal Construction Minster Klara Geywitz: No new apartments will come as a result of expropriation The new Federal Construction Minster Klara Geywitz (SPD) spoke against the expropriation of large housing corporations as has been required by a referendum in Berlin. “No new housing is created with expropriation, it just changes the way property is structured,” Geywitz said in an interview with the “Tagesspiegel” (Sunday). My goal is to give security to renters that their rent stays affordable in the years to come. A diverse mix of, for example, private landlords, cooperatives and housing associations is the best protection against the formation of a monopoly anyway. A coalition of the SPD, Greens and the Left would like to deploy an expert comission to figure out how best to handle the result of the referendum. If the situation does not calm itself down, Geywitz determined, discussions with the FDP in the Streetlight Coalition about further intensification of rental rights are not off the table. The coalition agreement stipulates a rent freeze extending to 2029, placing a limit on rental increases in tense housing markets along with the expansion of the rental index. I will speak with the Minister of Justice to order to implement this as quickly as possible. If the rental market does not become more bearable, then “we will speak with our partners in the coalition about further measures,” emphasized the SPD politician.

translation2: I am tired of Sky Sport F1  Hello F1 fans,  Over the course of the season, the quality on German Sky has been declining, so I wanted to take a moment to express my frustration with this. Today, during the F2 race, the broadcast was interrupted to start the F1 pre-race show. Although the start was delayed and there was an accident, it would have been possible to show the last (planned) ten minutes and the championship decision as well. It seems that due to legal reasons, F1 has priority and everything else has to be restricted, leaving Sky DE with no choice. However, this is still frustrating, especially since Sky UK is broadcasting the race to the end.  There is one positive aspect: the commentator Olivier Zwartyes did a good job handling the difficult situation surrounding the accident. However, there were some mistakes by the commentators Sascha Roos and Ralf Schumacher. They did not know that under a red flag, the tires could be changed. Although this situation occurred in Imola, Baku, and Silverstone this year, it was only when they received corresponding radio messages from Hamilton that they realized that Verstappen could change his tires. At Sky UK and RTL, the commentators knew immediately that this was possible.  In my opinion, such basic rules should be known when commenting on F1 for a pay-TV channel. It is also not the first time that it has been necessary to guess what is allowed or required by the rules. Both commentators have constant uncertainties in this area, which makes them appear unprofessional. For example, when ordering coffee from the (clueless) reporter Peter Hardenacke or when Ralf Schumacher says "UuuuuHD". The latter brings a lot of confusion to the commentary, which he apparently does not take seriously.  To make matters worse, the advertising takes over at Sky during the final lap. Sky is the only channel that goes into advertising during the race, as can be heard on F1TV. ServusTV and ORF do not do this. Additionally, both channels make less advertising during the training sessions than Sky, and this as a free-TV channel. Although we should thank Glock and Baumgartner for their work, this does not make up for the disadvantages. The rest of the program on Sky Sport F1 is also very poor and full of repeats.  In conclusion, Sky is the worst German-speaking channel for F1 coverage. RTL, on the other hand, does a better job, especially considering the advertising. So far, the F1 season has been much less enjoyable than it could have been with a better channel. I would be interested in hearing your thoughts on this.
reference: I am annoyed with Sky Sport F1 Hello F1 fans, the quality of German Sky decreased over the course of the season, such that I want to clear it up some with this post. First things first, today the transmission broke off in the middle of the F2 race in order to punctually begin the pre-show reporting of the F1. It was because of the delayed start and the falling accident that the schedule was so far behind what was planned, but you still could have let the last (planned) 10 minutes show as well as the tournament decision (!). Apparently because of legal reasons, F1 has priority and because of that everything else needs to be restricted such that Sky Germany didn’t really have a choice here. It is still dumb, because Sky UK transmitted the race up until the very end. In spite of that, some small praise: the announcer Olivier Zwartyes was a good accompaniment to the difficult situation and the unfortunate accident. In the F1 there was even knowledge gaps of the rules in the commentary by Sascha Roos and Ralf Schumacher, both of them didn’t know that during a red flag the tires are allowed to be changed. Although this situation already came up this year in Imola, Baku and Silverstone, they both first came to the conclusion that Verstappen was allowed to switch his tires following corresponding radio messages on the topic to Hamilton. The announcers at Sky UK and RTL knew immediately that this was a possibility for Verstappen. I am of the opinion that knowledge of such elementary rules should be assumed if you are going to provide F1 commentary on a paid-for TV broadcaster. It's also not the first guessing game as to what is possible or required by the rules, both of them have constant uncertainties regarding rules. In general I don’t really like the artificial style of the commentary from Roos, but I’ll admit that is a manner of taste. But even Heiko Wasser from RTL does it better in my honest opinion. Additionally, there are just absurdities, which make the two of them seem unprofessional, like the ordering of coffee with the (just as clueless) reporter Peter Hardenacke or the “Ahhhh HD” from Ralf Schumacher. This last part really brings a lot of agitation into the commentary which he doesn’t take seriously. Not least of all, the advertising is just so prevalent on Sky, in the cool-down lap Sky is the only broadcaster that still goes to commercials, like you can hear this on F1TV, because only the German audio track comes out without commentary right after the race. Neither ServusTV nor ORF do this. Both of these broadcasters also do less commercials than Sky during training, and they are free TV broadcasters. You even have to congratulate Glock and Baumgartner for their work, but that alone doesn’t cause me to overlook the disadvantages. The normal program from Sky Sport F1 is also very sparse and full of repetitions. All in all, Sky is really the worst German-speaking broadcaster that transmits the F1. In all honesty, RTL does a better job of transmitting the four races which they are allowed to transmit, including even the advertisements. At any rate, it really makes the grand F1 season considerably less fun as would be the case with a reasonable broadcaster. I would be really interested in your opinion.

translation2: I generally believe that it is not fair to ask children to take on the role of parents for their younger siblings. However, I think it is good for older siblings to help take care of the younger ones in moderation. They can take turns watching, helping, bringing drinks, etc. This teaches them responsibility, helps them contribute to the family, and makes them feel connected. As long as they are still young enough to be children themselves, I don't see any problems. If your K1 is comfortable being alone for a short time and it works for them, then that's fine. You know your children best, so it's up to you to decide what works for them. It's not fair to ask K1 to take care of K2 for too long, especially if something unexpected happens like a fire, break-in, earthquake, alien invasion, etc. That would be too much responsibility for K1 to handle. Whether this is a risk you are willing to take is up to you.
reference: I also think that as a general rule, children should not be expected to overtake a parental role for their younger siblings. However, I think it is also good for older siblings to care for the younger ones to some degree. Sometimes check-up on them, sometimes help, sometimes get the bottle, etc. They learn responsibility this way, help within the family and are thus connected with it. As long as they can continue to be a kid themselves, I don’t see the problem. If your first child looks after themselves alone for a short amount of time, that is OK, that is actually good. You can best get a sense of whether or not this works for your children. It is not as if they should change the second child’s diaper and sit for hours by them as they fall asleep. It is probably questionable from a strictly legal perspective. Maybe the psychologist would also have something to say about it. Since if something actually does happen, like a fire, break-in, earthquake, alien invasion, etc., it would be too much responsibility for child 1 to take care of child 2. If that is a risk that you would like to take that is up to you, of course ;)

translation2: Friedrich Nolte wins the 60th World Cup in the Two-Man Bob - Sports The Norwegian biathlete Ole Einar Björndalen's mark with 94 victories is the goal of the German bobsled pilot. "I had calculated it, I had to win 9.5 victories per season, then I could make it to Cortina 2026," said Nolte, the two-time Olympic gold medalist from BSC Oberbärenburg, who won two victories in two days at the races in Winterberg. On Saturday, he repelled Johannes Lochner's attack by 0.5 seconds, moving from third place to first. Then he made a slight adjustment to the material setup and won by 0.3 seconds on Sunday. With his teammates Thorsten Margis (SV Halle), Candy Bauer (BSC Oberbärenburg), and Alexander Schüller (SV Halle), he defeated the British Brad Hall. The Austrian Benjamin Maier finished third. "We took a bigger risk today and were rewarded," said Nolte, who also achieved his 22nd consecutive victory. The German Johannes Lochner, who had finished second the day before, came in fifth place this time. Christoph Hafer from BC Bad Feilnbach finished eighth after finishing fourth in the first race. "If I knew what he was doing differently, I would do it that way too," said Lochner. Nolte won with a home victory - podium for Jamanka In the women's competition, Laura Nolte won her third seasonal victory in the Two-Man Bob on her home track. After finishing fourth in the Monobob on Saturday, she won the World Cup on Sunday with Anschieberin Deborah Levi. Two-time Olympic gold medalist Mariama Jamanka from BRC Thüringen finished in second place with Germany's fastest sprinter, Alexandra Burghardt from Burghausen, as her teammate. She achieved her first podium finish of the season and also qualified for the Olympics. The Wiesbadener Kim Kalicki finished in third place with Leonie Fiebig. "For me, it was super cool, first podium finish in the World Cup, I'm super happy that Mariama took me with her," said Burghardt. "There's a lot of potential at the start, but the start times today were okay," she emphasized. Jamanka was slightly disappointed with the not entirely error-free runs, but said: "It's going in the right direction."
